entities.description: Eliza Rosanna Gilbert, Countess of Landsfeld, better known by the stage name Lola Montez, was an Irish dancer and actress who became famous as a Spanish dancer, courtesan, and mistress of King Ludwig I of Bavaria, who made her Gräfin von Landsfeld. heading: Deaths
txt: Horace Vernet, French painter (b. 1789)

entities.title: Horace Vernet
entities.description: Émile Jean-Horace Vernet, more commonly known as simply Horace Vernet, was a French painter of battles, portraits, and Orientalist subjects.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexander Dargomyzhsky, Russian composer (b. 1813)

entities.title: Alexander Dargomyzhsky
entities.description: Alexander Sergeyevich Dargomyzhsky was a 19th-century Russian composer. He bridged the gap in Russian opera composition between Mikhail Glinka and the later generation of The Five and Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky.

entities.description: William Robert Giblin was Premier of Tasmania (Australia) from 5 March 1878 until 20 December 1878 and from 1879 until 1884.

entities.title: Premier of Tasmania
entities.description: The Premier of Tasmania is the head of the executive government in the Australian state of Tasmania. By convention, the leader of the party or political grouping which has majority support in the House of Assembly is invited by the Governor of Tasmania to be Premier and principal adviser.

heading: Deaths
txt: Big Bear, Canadian tribal chief (b. 1825)

entities.title: Big Bear
entities.description: Big Bear, also known as Mistahi-maskwa, was a powerful and popular Cree chief who played many pivotal roles in Canadian history. He was appointed to chief of his band at the age of 40 upon the death of his father, Black Powder, under his father's harmonious and inclusive rule which directly impacted his own leadership. Big Bear is most notable for his involvement in Treaty 6 and the 1885 North-Wes

heading: Deaths
txt: George Bancroft, American historian and politician, 17th United States Secretary of the Navy (b. 1800)

entities.title: George Bancroft
entities.description: George Bancroft was an American historian and statesman who was prominent in promoting secondary education both in his home state and at the national and international levels. During his tenure as U.S. Secretary of the Navy, he established the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis in 1845. He was a senior American diplomat in Europe. Among his best-known writings is the magisterial series, Hist

entities.title: United States Secretary of the Navy
entities.description: The secretary of the Navy is a statutory officer and the head of the Department of the Navy, a military department within the United States Department of Defense.

heading: Deaths
txt: Rutherford B. Hayes, American general, lawyer, and politician, 19th President of the United States (b. 1822)

entities.title: Rutherford B. Hayes
entities.description: Rutherford Birchard Hayes was an American politician and attorney who served as the 19th president of the United States from 1877 to 1881, after serving in the U.S. House of Representatives and as governor of Ohio. entities.title: President of the United States
entities.description: The president of the United States (POTUS) is the head of state and head of government of the United States of America. The president directs the executive branch of the federal government and is the commander-in-chief of the United States Armed Forces.

entities.description: Sir Francis Villeneuve Smith was an English-born Australian lawyer, judge and politician, who was the fourth Premier of Tasmania from 12 May 1857 until 1 November 1860.

entities.title: Premier of Tasmania
entities.description: The Premier of Tasmania is the head of the executive government in the Australian state of Tasmania. By convention, the leader of the party or political grouping which has majority support in the House of Assembly is invited by the Governor of Tasmania to be Premier and principal adviser.

heading: Deaths
txt: Francis Galton, English polymath, anthropologist, and geographer (b. 1822)

entities.title: Francis Galton
entities.description: Sir Francis Galton, FRS, was an English Victorian era polymath: a statistician, sociologist, psychologist, anthropologist, tropical explorer, geographer, inventor, meteorologist, proto-geneticist, psychometrician and a proponent of social Darwinism, eugenics and scientific racism. He was knighted in 1909.

heading: Deaths
txt: Juliette Gordon Low, American founder of the Girl Scouts of the USA (b. 1860)

entities.title: Juliette Gordon Low
entities.description: Juliette Gordon Low was the founder of Girl Scouts of the USA. Inspired by the work of Lord Baden-Powell, founder of Boy Scouts, she joined the Girl Guide movement in England, forming her own group of Girl Guides there in 1911.

entities.title: Girl Scouts of the USA
entities.description: Girl Scouts of the United States of America (GSUSA), commonly referred to as simply Girl Scouts, is a youth organization for girls in the United States and American girls living abroad. Founded by Juliette Gordon Low in 1912, it was organized after Low met Robert Baden-Powell, the founder of Scouting, in 1911. heading: Deaths
txt: Gauhar Jaan, One of the first performers to record music on 78 rpm records in India. (b. 1873)

entities.title: Gauhar Jaan
entities.description: Gauhar Jaan was an Indian singer and dancer from Kolkata. She was one of the first performers to record music on 78 rpm records in India, which was later released by the Gramophone Company of India. entities.description: Ahmet Derviş also known as Derviş Bey or Derviş Pasha was an officer of the Ottoman Army and a general of the Turkish Army.

entities.description: The Victoria Cross (VC) is the highest and most prestigious award of the British honours system. It is awarded for valour "in the presence of the enemy" to members of the British Armed Forces. It may be awarded posthumously. txt: Louis Comfort Tiffany, American stained glass artist (b. 1848)

entities.title: Louis Comfort Tiffany
entities.description: Louis Comfort Tiffany was an American artist and designer who worked in the decorative arts and is best known for his work in stained glass. He is the American artist most associated with the Art Nouveau and Aesthetic movements. entities.title: Stained glass
entities.description: The term stained glass refers to coloured glass as a material and to works created from it. Throughout its thousand-year history, the term has been applied almost exclusively to the windows of churches and other significant religious buildings. heading: Deaths
txt: Mateiu Caragiale, Romanian journalist, author, and poet (b. 1885)

entities.title: Mateiu Caragiale
entities.description: Mateiu Ion Caragiale was a Romanian poet and prose writer, best known for his novel Craii de Curtea-Veche, which portrays the milieu of boyar descendants before and after World War I. Caragiale's style, associated with Symbolism, the Decadent movement of the fin de siècle, and early modernism, was an original element in the Romanian literature of the interwar period. heading: Deaths
txt: Walther von Reichenau, German field marshal (b. 1884)

entities.title: Walther von Reichenau
entities.description: Walter Karl Ernst August von Reichenau was a field marshal in the Wehrmacht of Nazi Germany during World War II. Reichenau commanded the 6th Army, during the invasions of Belgium and France. During Operation Barbarossa, the invasion of the Soviet Union, he continued to command the 6th Army as part of Army Group South as it captured Ukraine and advanced deep into Russia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pyotr Krasnov, Russian historian and general (b. 1869)

entities.title: Pyotr Krasnov
entities.description: Pyotr Nikolayevich Krasnov, sometimes referred to in English as Peter Krasnov, was a Don Cossack historian and officer, promoted to Lieutenant General of the Russian army when the revolution broke out in 1917, one of the leaders of the counter-revolutionary White movement afterwards and a Nazi collaborator who mobilized Cossack forces to fight against the Soviet Union during World War II.

heading: Deaths

heading: Deaths
txt: Jyoti Prasad Agarwala, Indian poet, playwright, and director (b. 1903)

entities.title: Jyoti Prasad Agarwala
entities.description: Jyoti Prasad Agarwala was a noted Indian playwright, songwriter, poet, writer and film maker from Assam. He was considered as Assamese cultural icon, deeply revered for his creative vision and output and is popularly called the Rupkonwar of Assamese culture. In fact, he is regarded as the founder of Assamese cinema for Joymoti (1935). His death anniversary is observed as Silpi divas in his honor.

heading: Deaths
txt: Walter Briggs Sr., American businessman (b. 1877)

entities.title: Walter Briggs Sr.
entities.description: Walter Owen Briggs Sr. was an American entrepreneur and professional sports owner. He was part-owner of the Detroit Tigers in Major League Baseball from 1919 to 1935, and then sole owner from 1935 to his death in 1952. heading: Deaths

entities.title: Patrice Lumumba
entities.description: Patrice Émery Lumumba was a Congolese politician and independence leader who served as the first Prime Minister of the independent Democratic Republic of the Congo from June until September 1960. He played a significant role in the transformation of the Congo from a colony of Belgium into an independent republic. entities.title: Prime Minister of the Democratic Republic of the Congo
entities.description: The prime minister of the Democratic Republic of the Congo is the head of government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The Constitution of the Third Republic grants the Prime Minister a significant amount of power.

entities.description: Simon Kovar was a 20th-century bassoonist and one of the most renowned teachers of the instrument.

entities.title: Bassoon

It is known for its distinctive tone color, wide range, versatility, and virtuosity. entities.title: Betty Smith
entities.description: Betty Smith was an American author. She is best known for her 1943 bestselling book A Tree Grows in Brooklyn.

txt: Dougal Haston, Scottish mountaineer (b. 1940)

entities.title: Dougal Haston
entities.description: Dougal Haston was a Scottish mountaineer famed for his exploits in the British Isles, Alps, and Himalayas. Later focusing on guiding and instruction, he became director of the International School of Mountaineering at Leysin, Switzerland, in 1967, a role which he held until his death in an avalanche while skiing above Leysin ten years later.

entities.description: Hugo Geronimo Fregonese was an Argentine film director and screenwriter who worked both in Hollywood and his home country.

His affair with Christine Keeler resulted in another of her lovers, John Profumo, resigning from the United Kingdom government, in what became known as the Profumo affair.
